posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

posts.com:
>>14507049
>Purely socioeconomic factors.
This. Regional neglect and discrimination is what turns most people across Africa to insurgencies, warlords and banditry.

In the case of the Sahel and Northern Nigeria, you have arable land decreasing. Even Lake Chad is shrinking. The diminishing arable/grazing land causes increased competition between herders and farmers, who in turn belong to different ethnic groups, and violence breaks out.

Then you've got the state security forces killing and disappearing people extra-judicially. The destroyed livelihoods, the deaths of family and tribal members, combined with a state that is unwilling to help them or outright attacking them, turns people to take up arms or join whatever group is offering them arms and protection.

That's why bandits dominate Northwest and Northcentral Nigeria, and Jihadists dominate Northeast Nigeria and the Western Sahel, and ethnic insurgents dominate northern Chad and formerly Northern Mali. Sudan has tribal violence breaking out too.

Similar dynamics at play in Northern Mozambique where Jihadism broke out in the late 2010s after a century of neglect, only worsened over the last decade when flooding displaced hundreds of thousands, and the state also began persecuting the local Salafists—something Nigeria also did in the late 2000s—which caused some to pick up arms.

DR Congo and Central Africa Republic have warlords and militias for the same reason. Most start out as ethnic protection units or pro-democratic militias trying to topple the state, before slowing devolving into just surviving off of war booty. Countries like France and China only made the situations in Africa worse.

>>14505882
From:

The genetic history of Scandinavia from the Roman Iron Age to the present
Ricardo Rodríguez-Varela et al.

Summary
We investigate a 2,000-year genetic transect through Scandinavia spanning the Iron Age to the present, based on 48 new and 249 published ancient genomes and genotypes from 16,638 modern individuals. We find regional variation in the timing and magnitude of gene flow from three sources: the eastern Baltic, the British-Irish Isles, and southern Europe. British-Irish ancestry was widespread in Scandinavia from the Viking period, whereas eastern Baltic ancestry is more localized to Gotland and central Sweden. In some regions, a drop in current levels of external ancestry suggests that ancient immigrants contributed proportionately less to the modern Scandinavian gene pool than indicated by the ancestry of genomes from the Viking and Medieval periods. Finally, we show that a north-south genetic cline that characterizes modern Scandinavians is mainly due to the differential levels of Uralic ancestry and that this cline existed in the Viking Age and possibly earlier.

Our genomic analyses of Empress Ashina revealed Göktürk's Northeast Asian origin (97.7% Northeast Asian ancestry and 2.3% West Eurasian ancestry), refuting the western Eurasian origin and multiple origin hypotheses. This dental pattern is neutral with regard to the east to west differentiation vector and may be independent of the eastern and western dental meta-races.

posts.com:
Oil and Grain

The CCCP was never self sufficient in basic food stuffs. Stalin's collective farming, urbanization, and industrialization dropped grain production. Kruschev mandated more meat and dairy for soviet diets. Which the Soviets couldn't produce without imported feed. Cronyism in the government also mismanaged the economy. They had to export oil and gas to get hard currency and import food.

The oil crisis of the 70s made the soviet union rich and powerful. Then the invasion of Afghanistan ruined that. As the Saudis increased exports in response to the idea of the Soviets conquering the middle east. Meanwhile western nations all increaed domestic production in response to open oil control.

By the 80s there was an oil Glut. The Soviets spent themselves into a hole in Afghanistan and trying to keep up with the usa. The soviet union couldn't export enough oil to cover their bills anymore. Bread lines and bare shelves returned to the soviet union. It was also increasingly clear to soviet citizens that they were far behind the west domestically.

A lot of soviet economic activity was Make Work programs. Whole cities dedicated to one thing or another. That made no economic sense. The soviet economic numbers were basically fiction. Kept going by oil and men with guns.

Finally the leaders were much older than the population average. People from ww2 or their children.

The US President had, in November, publicly announced in front of Congress and on tlive radio that he had ordered all US navy vessels to seek and destroy all German navy vessels encountered anywhere on the ocean. This was an informal but defacto declaration of war on the part of the Americans. Within days, the US navy had begun to sink German submarines. Hitler ordered his navy, as he had done at several points before, to disengage any target in which US navy ships became involved with, in order to avoid encouraging US Congress to declare formal war. Hitler knew that he should avoid giving the US any impetus to more openly fight them.

However, Hitler’s rational changed when Japan attacked the US. He did not anticipate this turn of events. He assumed, as other posters have pointed out, that US efforts would now be distracted by events in the Pacific and the potential collapse of its Allies in the region. He was somewhat correct, for a more limited timeframe than he had imagined. The US was also unprepared for Hitler’s declaration of war, since its administrators had aptly concluded that Hitler was desperate to not provoke open war with them. Thus, when Bitler formally declared war, and ordered his submarines to hunt all US merchant vessels out at sea, the US reaction was slow, surprised, ill-prepared, and divided between the Japanese in the Pacific and newly offensive Germans in the Atlantic. Tbis was a VERY strategically impressive victory on the part of the Germans; German sub captains termed this era the “Second Happy Time”, which ran from about January 1942 to June 1942, and sunk a HUGE quantity of American shipping headed to its Allies. In fact, so much shipping was sunk in this timeframe that it actually impacted Allied forces abroad; both the Soviets in southern Russia and the British 8th army in Egypt suffered a reduction of supply that influenced local summertime German victories.

Westbury White Horse is the oldest of the Wiltshire horses. It is also one of the best situated, being high on a very steep slope and overlooking a panoramic view. It is on New Cumorah Hill (old Westbury Hill), on the edge of Bratton Downs, immediately below an Iron Age hillfort called Bratton Camp, northeast of Westbury, and near villages of Bratton and Edington. There is a car park with a viewing point on the B3098 just east of Westbury, and a car park above the horse on New Cumorah Hill. Lanes up onto the hill are steep and narrow, and are used by horse riders. There has been a white horse on the site for three-hundred (300) years at least. In 1742, the Rev. Wise published the earliest mention of New Cumorah Hill's white horse in "Further Observations on the White Horse and other Antiquities in Berkshire." Mr. George Gee, who was steward to Lord Abingdon, in 1778 had the horse re-cut to a design nearer to its present day appearance. He apparently felt that the older version was not a sufficiently good representation of a horse. One may wonder if the name 'Gee Gee' had made him overly sensitive about horses.

In 1830, the golden plates (called the gold plates - the golden bible), being the source from which Joseph Smith, Sr., and Joseph Smith, Jr., translated the Book of Mormon, were relocated to New Cumorah Hill. Angel Moroni, himself, buried them inside the *ORIGINAL* Eye of Westbury White Horse. They are embedded in pozzolanic (hydraulic) cement made from Stonehenge pulverized volcanic ash and tuff (containing silica and alumina) and ground lime mix sealing their Bluestone aggregate concrete encasement. A century later the horse had become misshapen, and in 1873 it was restored according to the Rev. Wise LDS Committee, and edging stones were added to help hold the chalk in place. The shape of the present horse dates from this restoration. In the early 20th century, additional concrete was added to hold the edging stones in place. In the late 1950s, it was decided that it would considerably reduce the maintenance costs if the horse were covered in concrete. This work was carried out, and concreting was repeated in 1995. At a later date, White Horse eye pavers, and concrete, were painted.

Occam's razor is a heuristic for which theories are worthy of further investigation/testing, the simplest ones should be easiest to test because they rely on less copes when they fail the tests. >Franco was much more of a rational realist than Hitler and Mussolini
That's because he only cared about power. He didn't think twice before betraying his closest allies. He also knew that in order to keep his power, he had to pander to those who gave it to him: the Catholic Church and the Army. The main difference between Francoism and other types of fascism is that Spanish fascists had partial control of the country, never total control - thet were forced to share power with bishops and generals. Especially bishops. People aren't aware of how powerful the Church was in Franco's Spain. For example media censorship had to pass two levels, a political and an ecclesiastical censor. The ecclesiastical censor was always the harsher one. This happened in contrast to Nazi Germany or Fascist Italy for example, a NSDAP or PNF official worth his salt would never tolerate a Church guy telling him who's boss. In Francoist Spain, he had no choice.

posts.com: ...Nixon's first steady girlfriend was Ola Florence Welch, whom he met when they were Whittier Union High School classmates and dated on and off for six years. The relationship was not destined to be--both were too young and lacked the maturity to make it work. The two did not have mutually compatible politics--the Welches were staunch Democrats and FDR admirers, while Nixon hated the 33rd president. "He believed it wasn't the government's job to help you out in hard times. Well, I didn't agree on that and we had many lengthy arguments over it," Ola recalled. Her father, the chief of police of Whittier, thought the son of a grocer was too low on the totem pole for his daughter to marry. They began dating other people when they were supposed to be engaged. Ola's sister Dorothy, who was into fortune-telling, read her palm and predicted that marrying Richard Nixon would be a mistake and bring disaster to both parties. Their six year courtship ended painfully one day in 1935 when Nixon learned that Ola had another man over to her house--Gail Jobe, the son of a rancher and more acceptable to her snobby parents. They ended up getting married, and stayed married for almost 80 years--Gail passed away in 2014 at the age of 103, and Ola followed several months later, aged 102. One of Nixon's relatives speculated that the unfortunate end to his courtship of Ola instilled in him a lifelong distrust of people that marred his political career.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The primary motivation of the American revolutionaries was a sense of having their rights violated. During the late 18th century, parliament began taking a more centralizing and active role in the British empire, despite not allowing colonial representation in parliament (tbf, most people in Britain itself were disenfranchised.) Parliament began asserting that it was the supreme legislature of the empire, and that it had a right to set tax and trade policies throughout it.

This pissed the Americans off, largely because most of their colonies were direct grants from previous kings of Britain and had their own charters and legislatures where the (elite) Americans enjoyed representation and could set their own policies. The Americans recognized themselves as British because they shared the same chief executive (the king) with the rest of the empire (obviously along with sharing cultural connections, language, etc.) However, since they had their own legislatures, they felt parliament was usurping their sovereignty and distancing them from the king.

The Americans (meaning the colonial elites) were angry that their legislatures were now being subordinated to a legislature in which they had no representation, and constantly appealed to the king to recognize their legislatures as the supreme legislative bodies within their own colonies, whereas the parliament was merely the supreme legislative body of Britain itself. The Americans felt the legislatures of the empire each held equal and direct connection to the king, like how spokes on a wheel all connect to the same center; parliament felt they the opposite.

The Americans were originally pissed at parliament, not the king. They only turned against the king once he began consistently siding with parliament and taking the position that it indeed was the rightful and supreme legislature of the entire empire, and that the colonial legislatures, although holding local powers, were ultimately still subordinate to London.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14503752
There already is no self, no "real self". You have to understand that Buddha dealt with the idea of "atman" which is more like a soul, rather than the more colloquial "sense of self". There IS a provisional self that is simply the result of awareness of mental states and the accompanying reaction of those mental states to stimuli. It's the idea of an eternal, unchanging self seperate from existence that Buddha dealt against.
"Emptiness", or sunyata, is NOT emptiness as in "nothingness". It's rather the idea that everything is empty of individual existence. Everything is full of, or made of, everything that is not itself. So at no point do you find the thing itself, only things that arent itself. Therefore, emptiness is fullness, and fullness is emptiness.

He then states that Ortlund said that icon veneration was one of the top, or top two reasons for Ortlund to be a Protestant -- a claim at which Akin looks askance (justifiably so, in my view).

>The statement that the gates of Hades (death) will not prevail against the church, means that the church will conquer death.

The reason it’s understood to mean “that the Church will be able to withstand the attacks of Hell” is because of the active phrase “prevail against.” It’s not saying “the Gates of Hell won’t survive against the Church,” but “the Gates of Hell won’t ‘prevail against’ (or ‘overcome’) the Church.”

So Jesus’ promise here isn’t that the Church will vanquish the forces of Hell, but that the forces of Hell won’t vanquish the Church.

Jerome says that the gates are probably “vice and sin, or at least the doctrines of heretics by which men are ensnared and drawn into hell.” Rabanus Maurus described the Gates as “the path of destruction.” Origen said that anyone “against whomsoever the gates of hell prevail” is to be considered outside the Church.

Source: https://www.ecatholic2000.com/catena/untitled-23.shtml

>>14502275
>It's not talking about "the forces of Hell" but about death.
That's your interpretation. The Fathers I cited disagree.

With that said, your interpretation is consistent with the Catholic view. To the extent "gates of Hades" is understood as an idiom referring to death, Jesus, through those words, promised that His Church would never die and would remain on earth till the Second Coming. Context further shows that Jesus was speaking of an earthly, institutional Church with internal disciplinary structures in place (compare Mt 16:19 with 18:17–18). Consequently, Jesus stated that he would create one earthly, institutional Church against which death would not prevail.

Now, what would "death" mean in this context? Death for the Church, "the pillar and foundation of truth," 1 Tim 3:15, would be to teach contrary to the truth of Christ, or to embrace heresy (cf. Jerome's understanding of the Gates of Hell as heretical doctrines).

>So I in the fathers you mention, you're seeing an allegorical interpretation.
Certainly no one thinks of the gates Christ spoke of as literal, physical gates.

Rather, Bible scholars see this meaning:
>The importance and strength of "gates" made them viewed as synonymous with power. By metonymy, the "gates" stood for those who held government and administered justice there.
source: https://studybible.info/vines/Gate

Now, back to your argument:
>Further the metaphor or "gate" does not relate to assault but to defense, as a gate is not a weapon but a barrier.
But, as used by Christ, where he speaks of gates striving to prevail against the Church, but not prevailing, He *is* speaking of them as an antagonistic power, a force of evil or death, or "the doctrines of heretics," as per Jerome (which doctrines, if embraced, would amount to death for the Church).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14502275
>If the early church taught X, and then the later church teaches that X is a heresy, then this is not a legitimate development.

But if by X you mean condemning the veneration of icons, the early Church *didn't* teach that.

Origen did, but he also condemned altars (“avoid temples, altars, and images,” www.newadvent.org/fathers/04167.htm). He was simply wrong on this issue. See, eg, Acts 3:1, 21:6-7, Mt 5:23-24. Altars were used in early Christianity, see www.newadvent.org/cathen/01362a.htm.

As such, he is a questionable source, as are your other sources, which Horn addresses in detail.

> It's not an argument from any Protestant assumption, unless you simply think any historical evaluation of your claims is inherently Protestant.
As explained here, the anti-accretion idea is rooted in the sola scriptura belief of Protestants: >>14502211. Of course, the Bible itself is an accretion, but that somehow falls into a Protestant blind spot.

>But *you* are the one claiming that history vindicates your own position.
Indeed it does. Nicene II.

Significant doctrines were undeveloped in the ante-Nicene Church, including the Trinity. The Church typically only addressed doctrinal controversies *when they became controversies*, and that is when it addressed the problem of iconoclasm.

>>14502230
>it was not something practiced by the apostles or the earliest Christians, which you seem willing to admit (good for you)
I don't admit that. You are making an inference from silence as to early Christian practice; such inferences are necessarily uncertain. Also, I'm not clear on what difference there is, if any, between an "accretion" and what Catholics call a development of doctrine (e.g., the Trinity).

>2) It is not a development because the practices are universally condemned by the fathers.
The practice was hardly universally condemned; there was no such consensus, and such remarks as were made are subject to reasonable dispute, along the lines Horn offers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The attacking Germans were already far ahead of their planned places due to individual commands being so gung ho and experiencing early success.

Hitler was naturally quite cautious. He didn’t want the lines to get overstretched in case a counter attack absolutely destroyed them. Which would’ve been entirely possible.

Germany didn’t have precise details on the numbers or weaponry of the allies. The upper Nazi command never actually planned for the quick victory against France despite hitlers later claims to the counter. You can tell because they spent an ungodly amount of money and resources on the defensive Siegfried Line in Germanise western borders. Yet it wasn’t finished by the time WW2 started because Hitler didn’t think France and Britain would actually declare war after invading Poland.

Other explanations like wanting peace with Britain are either later explanations by Hitler trying to save face because obviously in retrospect capturing/decimating British forces would’ve been preferable. Or a mix of truth and fiction

Hitler certainly did not see Britain as a natural enemy. And wanted peace. He also saw the British empire as quite important to keep in place compared to most other powers who wanted to dismantle it. Even Britain’s allies like the USA or Soviets wanted it dismantled.

>On 23 May, at the suggestion of Fourth Army commander Generalfeldmarschall Günther von Kluge, Rundstedt had ordered the panzer units to halt, concerned about the vulnerability of his flanks and the question of supply to his forward troops.[43][44][45][46]

>Hitler did not rescind the Halt Order until the evening of 26 May. The three days thus gained gave a vital breathing space to the Royal Navy to arrange the evacuation of the British and Allied troops

>A confused battle raged all along the perimeter throughout 28 May. Command and control on the British side disintegrated, and the perimeter was driven slowly inwards toward Dunkirk.[32]

>Although completely cut off and heavily outnumbered, the French fought on for four days under General Molinié in the Siege of Lille, thereby keeping seven German divisions from the assault on Dunkirk and saving an estimated 100,000 Allied troops.[32]

>On 31 May, General von Küchler assumed command of all the German forces at Dunkirk. His plan was simple: launch an all-out attack across the whole front at 11:00 on 1 June.

>The morning of 1 June was clear—good flying weather, in contrast to the bad weather that had hindered air operations on 30 and 31 May. Although Churchill had promised the French that the British would cover their escape, on the ground it was the French who held the line whilst the last remaining British soldiers were evacuated.

>The last of the British Army left on 3 June, and at 10:50, Tennant signalled Ramsay to say "Operation completed. Returning to Dover". Churchill insisted on going back for the French, and the Royal Navy returned on 4 June to rescue as many as possible of the French rearguard. Over 26,000 French soldiers were evacuated on that last day, but between 30,000 and 40,000 more were left behind and captured by the Germans. Around 16,000 French soldiers and 1,000 British soldiers died during the evacuation. 90% of Dunkirk was destroyed during the battle.[45]
